GAME
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4576 A
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PEBBLES, HIDE, CORD, FUR, SHELL
Dimensions: L:20 W:14 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: GAME
Category: RECREATIONAL ARTIFACTS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EMBAGARA. A sort of pocket worn on the back also in the front. The fresh skin of the animals are filled with sand and then dried in the sun. No. 1452 is from a ground squirrel and contains the little iron ore pebbles = AMANGA, with which the men and boys play passionately. They play at four-four pebbles or a number of pebbles divisible by four wins. Generally arrows are played.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

SOIL SAMPLES
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4577
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PAPER, CERAMIC
Dimensions: IN BOX) L:16 W:14.2 H:7.9 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: SOIL
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: Samples of the soil of which the MANGBETU make their pottery NEBU = the yellowish or whitish kind is found in pockets along the courses of water, ESUBOBE = the dark kind is taken from large termite hills. There is one package bearing the same No. showing the sausages as they are made before laying them around. The third package shows a piece of a large pot cut out when the sausages were put on and dried. It shows the process well (before smoothening) down.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

TOP, TOY
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4579 A
Culture: MANGBETU, MEDJE
Locale: RUNGU
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: GOURD, WOOD, CORD, PITCH
Dimensions: L:10 W:1.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: TOP, TOY
Category: RECREATIONAL ARTIFACTS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: [One of] Two tops used by children of the MANGBETU and also the MEDJE. To make it spin proceed as follows: the string is put through the hole of the second stick so they are placed together. The end of the string is placed up, but also downward. The longer end of the top and the string is then from below or above rolled up or downward close together until the two sticks meet. The stick at the end of the string is held in the left or sometimes right hand, the other stick with the hole in its upper end is held by the right (or left) hand at right angle with the other so the crossed sticks hold the top in position pushed off rapidly that sets the top spinning with a loud buzzing noise. They say it is a rather recent invention of their children (probably introduced from some other tribe) and call it MEHEDE or MAYEHEDE. The fruit also used as a clapper for children is from a bush called ABASINGA. NOTE: Sometimes 10 or more children may be seen to amuse themselves on the open place of their villages. With these tops the loudest [illeg] is considered the most [illeg].
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

POTTERY TOOL
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4580 A
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, CALABASH, SHELL
Dimensions: L:23.5 W:1.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: POTTERY TOOL
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: OWARRA. Tools for making large pottery. The piece of calabash and the shell serve when dipped into the water to smoothen down the surface. The piece of (raffia) wood is used to cut or smoothen down. The piece of rattan knotted once is the only measure used to maintain the same thickness in large pots. They dip it in water and draw it over the edge, the tip of the fingers only slightly reaching beyond. There are several small cut pieces of wood with which the pottery when slightly dry is decorated by rolling it over. These pieces are dipped from time to time into water.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Wood, gourd and shell tools for making pottery. The gourd and shell were used to smooth the surface of the pots, the wooden stick served to cut and smooth the clay, and the wooden roulettes were rolled over the slightly dry pots to create patterns and textures.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BARK/LEAVES/WOOD
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4581
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: BARK, LEAVES, WOOD, PIGMENT
Dimensions: (BOX) L:23.4 W:14.5 H:7.9 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BARK, LEAF, WOOD
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EGAKU. The string with which women and some men tie up their head, also used for children. It is made by women from bast of the raffia palm. Photographs have been taken of the manner of braiding and two of the sticks = GADOKIRRA upon which the string is braided are in the collection No. lll3, lll4. The string is blackened by crushing the leaves and bark of a tree = EPADA, (see sample No. lll5) putting it into water and washing it in the maceration received. Without drying it the string is put into the mud for a day and in this way becomes very black. (This is the first time I hear of the addition of the leaves and bark of this tree to blacken objects.) The interpreter I took with me from MEDJE says now that the MEDJE also use the bark and leaves of a tree (but not the same). The same bark and leaves or rather the maceration of it is used for blackening pots. It is in this process I saw it first time employed. It is put on when the jars are still hot during the process of backing them. After blackening the string is cleaned of all the small outstanding pieces. No. 1112 is fastened to a form of wood so the perfectness and size may be seen at once and especially in order to smoothen out all possible knicks, as the form has about the circumference of a human head, the arrangement is perfect. See photographs. Nearly all women know how to braid the string.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
WRIST PAD
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4582
Culture: BANGBA (ABANGBA)

Keywords: WRIST PAD
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ABONGO. A wrist pad for archers made by an ABANGBA, not in common use hereabout, but commonly used by the MOMVU. The skin of an animal; GENNAL monkey, and the tails turned inside so as to form a holster.

BRACELET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4583
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: NAILS (FINGER+TOE), BEADS, CORD
Dimensions: L:18.5 W:11 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BRACELET
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: DEGGE = fingernails. A bracelet made out of the fingernails and toenails of NENSIMA. She presented the bracelet in assuring me of her love and friendly sentiments. When NIANGARA died she also cut her fingernails and afterwards presented the necklace, I believe, to Commandant A. CHRISTIAENS at NIANGARA. It needed special permission of the king, who in the presence of NENSIMA presented these strung up claws. They usually are only cut off in case of mourning like the hair which is thrown upon the roof of the hut in which the dead chief is buried. It is a sign of distinction as everyone can notice that no hard work is performed by its bearer.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

SKIN STAMPING TOOL
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4587 A
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: GOURD, WOOD, PLANT FIBER, PIGMENT
Dimensions: L:5 W:1 H:2.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: SKIN STAMPING TOOL
Category: EQUIPMENT
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ANGQUEDE. An assortment of pieces used by women in painting, stamping or rolling upon their skin. These different pieces moistened with the juice of gardenia that generally is rubbed down in a [illeg: pot?] with charcoal. The decoration generally lasts 4 or 5 days. They rub their bodies then with leaves dipped in water or wash and start anew.
Exhibition History
• MUTILATE?. MUSEUM OF CONTEMPORARY ART, ANTWERP, ANTWERPEN, BELGIUM. May 2001 - October 2001
• BODY ART: MARKS OF IDENTITY. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. November 1999 - May 2000
Exhibition Label: Body painting stamp. Wood, vegetable fiber, gourd, paint. Late 19th-early 20th century. Stamps were dipped in paint and then applied to the skin. Fine lines were traced using a stick between the stamped patterns. The same dyes and stamps were also used to decorate bark cloth, and roulettes were also used to decorate pottery.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

DRUM STICK
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4589
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, LEATHER, CORD, RUBBER
Dimensions: L:33.2 W:4.1 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: DRUMSTICK
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGUDU. A drum beaten with sticks covered at their end with rubber. (Given as bu-bu-bu-bu) Beaten usually with accompaniment of tubular instruments like 2002-2003. It is quite curious how the musicians follow their chief wherever he goes on dances and how long they can blow these horns without interruption. Often the chief stops, one of the principal women indicates the direction the horns should point which causes a very considerable change. The din is greatest when they are pointed towards the ground and as they slowly turn them upward, to the right or the left the sounds become more agreeable.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
GONG BEATER
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4590
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, COMPOSITE, STAIN
Dimensions: L:29.2 W:4.9 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: GONG BEATER
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EDUNDU. A large flat gong used at dances, to announce the arrival of the chief, also to announce the drinking of beer or wine of a chief. It is beaten with a stick surrounded by a knob of rubber. When beating it they pass their left arm through the handle, the gong resting then upon the hand. With the right hand it is beaten. The sound carries considerable distance about 600 to 800 yards.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
APRON
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4594
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER, LEAVES
Dimensions: L:27.5 W:9.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: APRON
Category: COSTUME
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NEGWE. The portion of their clothes that covers their hind. It is very simply adjusted. The lengthened piece on the back is simply pushed down the natural furrow, the string between the narrow and flat piece. The MANGBETU women do not like that their hind quarters are exposed to the looks of men, but when making their toilet they are well satisfied to take a piece not larger than the width of a finger for covering this portion of their backside. In front they take then a piece of bark cloth the size of their hand, so as to cover just that portion which is covered with hair. In this one branch the women create the most astonishing variety of patterns and each woman changes the pattern continually. Some even decorate it by cutting in black human figures, monkeys, etc. (See Nos. 1050 - 1051). As a rule they use only banana leaves in making them. The rough blackened leaves are the reddish leaves that cover the long flours [sic, flowers?] of plantains. They are easily blackened and have a greater resistance. They also use occasionally leaves of corn. They are very white ones, like No. 1022. Others have a sort of hood, like Nos. 1017, 1031, 1032, 1034, which very nicely covers the hollow near the base of the spine. Formerly much in use, now it is difficult to get them. There are only two women in the village of OKONDO who know how to make them. They are woven of bast. Some have a lengthened portion that lays flat on the back like No. l018 & 1049. They arrange first the leaves and s...ew bast through. They sometimes produce good patterns as may be seen also by Nos. 986, 988, 983 & 985. Very few of the women are able to do this kind of work. Usually it takes about a day to make one of these covers for their back, but they never work continuously. As may be seen by No. 1052, the leaves are first sliced deep and pressed between the mats of their bed. They sleep upon a week or so sometimes there are several bunches like this between the mats for future working. The outside leaves are then collected and blackened. They usually work one hour or two in the morning (before they go to other work) in making these covers and in this may spend several days. The women admire the creations of their friends and the more experienced ones very often give their welcome advice. No. 1055 shows the beginning of a cover. They only use a needle, (best to sew and tie) a pointed stick (to make the knot) a knife to cut the designs. The designs are cut out without making preliminary indications for the pattern (free hand).Show More >>
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition
 
 
HAT DECORATION
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4595
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: FEATHERS, BONE, BARK CLOTH, CORD
Dimensions: L:30 D:20 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: HAT DECORATION
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: NOTUKU. The king's hat in which he danced and was photographed. It was difficult to get it, he would not like to depart with the large bunch of cut feathers from a harpy-like eagle, which is very scarce. The bird is called 'ETUMU.' This bunch hangs down behind. In front the bunch of red feathers mounted on a bone pin is fastened. They call them 'NOMBROKUDU.' On the sides he had two huge bunches made of the feathers of guinea fowls, unfortunately he had given them away. OKONDO gave me at the same time the small bunch of red feathers to be fastened on top of the hats.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Feathers on a bone rod. They were attached to the front of a basketry hat and worn by Chief Okondo for dances.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

IMPLEMENT, AXE
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4600
Culture: MANGBETU?, ZANDE?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: STONE (HEMATITIE)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: AX
Category: EQUIPMENT
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Related Photographs
Field Notes: [One of five] Prehistoric stone implements of HEMATITE called by the MANGBETU 'NABARAKUMBI' by the AZANDE '[illeg: IMBIA?']. Both tribes believe that these are the axes of the lightning and they hold that trees, huts and human beings are destroyed with them. The latter is a fine specimen measuring of 31? mm. in length and 48 mm. wide. No. 2115 has been presented by Monsieur l'Adjoint Superieur de l'Uele Maurice Siffen [or Siffer?].

SAMPLES, SOIL
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4609 AB
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: SOIL, EARTH, CLAY, PAPER
Dimensions: BOXES) A) L:15.2 W:8.3 B) L:15.2 W:8.3 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: SOIL
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: Samples of the soil of which the MANGBETU make their pottery NEBU = the yellowish or whitish kind is found in pockets along the courses of water, ESUBOBE = the dark kind is taken from large termite hills. There is one package bearing the same No. showing the sausages as they are made before laying them around. The third package shows a piece of a large pot cut out when the sausages were put on and dried. It shows the process well (before smoothening) down.

RATTLE
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4612
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)

Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EDIDI. A sort of clapper--a round stick-like arrangement which is from time to time turned in order to ensure the ever rattling noise. It is held in the right hand and shaken up and down. Sometimes it is even struck on the ground. Used during dances, not in common use.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Wooden dancing staff covered with leaves. The dancer shook and turned it to produce a rattling sound and occasionally struck it on the ground.

MAT
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4613
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, PLANT FIBER
Dimensions: L:189 W:126 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: MAT
Category: FURNISHINGS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: EKANGA. Mats of the leafstalks of the raffia palm. These mats are used to adjust down upon them. Objects destined for the king or persons of his closer family never touch the ground. They are always put upon a mat. Thus I saw them cut an OKAPI belt, the board was laid upon the mat, and OKONDO himself surveyed the cutting. When the brass nails were driven into the stools of MTUMBANI and NENSIMA, the stool was put on a mat. OKONDO has a large mat 520 ctm. long and 645 ctm. wide upon which the principal persons engaged in a palaver generally squat. The children who are adopted by OKONDO generally play on a mat. If the women arrange their hair, they generally stretch out on a mat or also on a bench.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

HORN
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4618
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: IVORY
Dimensions: L:138 W:12.6 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: MUSICAL INSTRUMENT HORN
Category: SOUND DEVICES
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Related Photographs
Curatorial Notes: The Mangbetu are groups of linguistically and culturally related peoples in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Like many neighboring West African peoples, their rich musical heritage has an important role in their communities.

Ivory horns were vital instruments for Mangbetu royalty; ivory has long been held as a highly prized material. The use of this precious ivory and the special labor involved in its production firmly linked ivory horns with the power of the king. Ivory horn production was delegated to exceptional smiths who used metals tools to carve the instrument from an animal tusk; these smiths also carved decorative images and motifs on the exterior of the horn, as seen on object 90.1/ 1794. Herbert Lang, head of the Museums 1915 Congo expedition during which these horns were collected, noted that many of these horns were adorned with an anthropomorphic carving on the mouthpiece, a decorative motif also found on Mangbetu harps. The length of the horns could be extended by attaching a wooden tube to the larger end of the instrument, a device that also deepened the sound of the horn. (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 202)

Ivory horn orchestras were primarily employed during court dances, such as the mabolo dance, in which the king danced alone in front of his subjects order to display his skill. The mabolo dance was designed to affirm the kings prestige because skillful dancing is equated with intelligence (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 205). Large ivory horns were also used to announce certain royal events, such as the mabolo dance, as well as the arrival and departure of a king, and victories in war. Smaller ivory horns, such as object 90.1/3660, were also carried by women during royal dances. Ivory horns were used to honor chiefs during the colonial period. (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 203).

Felix, Marc Leo. White Gold, Black Hands: Ivory Sculpture in Congo. Qiquhar, Heilungkiang, China: Gemini Sun, 2010.

Schildkrout, Enid, and Curtis A. Keim. African Reflections: Art from Northeastern Zaire. Seattle: U of Washington, 1990.

Research: Ava Muhr 2014
Field Notes: NAMBONGO NOKANDRE. Large ivory horn with a woman's figure on the upper end, 146 ctm. long. Made by artist of Chief OKONDO.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Ivory horn, carved by an artist of Chief Okondo's court. Instruments for the king's orchestra were made and sounded at his request.
Publication History
• WHITE GOLD, BLACK HANDS: IVORY SCULPTURE IN CONGO VOL. 7. FELIX, MARK LEO, EDITOR. 2014
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BELLOWS
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4620
Culture: ZANDE
Locale: EAST OF YAKULUKU
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, FIBER CORD, HIDE, FUR
Dimensions: L:64 W:34 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BELLOWS
Category: EQUIPMENT
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: MBITI. [One of] Two bellows carved in wood and covered with hide. The projecting tube is put into a cylindrical tube of dried clay mixed with broken stalks or fibres from grasses. This heavy tube only reaches the fire. The bellows are worked by a boy alternately by pulling on the string fixed in the center of the slightly tightened skin. They often work without many iron tools and use an assortment of roundish pebbles to beat the red hot iron, though for finishing their rather poor work they use a sort of hammer fixed to a split or forked stick. The AZANDE towards YAKULUKU are only very poor blacksmiths and hardly produce but some sort of hoes or lumbs [sic, lumps?] of molten iron used as money. The AZANDE towards POKO, NALA, near DUNGU on the contrary are just as experienced in working iron as the MANGBETU, as may be seen from the specimens. NOTE: From AZANDE east of YAKULUKU.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

BARK CLOTH BEATER

Share Object

Field Notes: [One of] Three sort of ladles carved in ivory.
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Ivory spatula. Ivory horns, barkcloth beaters and jewelry were made throughout the region in the 19th century, although elephants were rarely killed just for their tusks. The commercial value of ivory increased dramatically in the 1860s when Arab and European caravans began exporting large quantities. In the colonial period, Mangbetu carvers produced a variety of purely ornamental objects, many made for foreigners.
Publication History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. SCHILDKROUT, ENID AND CURTIS KEIM. EXHIBITION CATALOG. 1990
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

XYLOPHONE
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4647
Culture: ZANDE?
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: WOOD, CORD, GOURD, PLANT FIBER, COATING
Dimensions: L:74.5 W:90 H:31 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: XYLOPHONE
Category: SOUND DEVICES
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Wooden xylophone with gourd resonators. Xylophones, never adopted by the Mangbetu and rare among the Azande, were generally reserved for chiefs and could be played only at court. The musician placed the curved wooden handle around his body, with the end under his seat. By pressing against the handle with his legs, he kept the gourd resonators suspended above the ground.
Manuscript Catalog Related Archives Finding Aids About Lang-Chapin Congo Expedition

JAR
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4693 A
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: CLAY
Dimensions: L:27 W:11 H:23.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: DOUBLE JAR
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: MANGBETU pottery with two heads.
Exhibition History
• ECHOING IMAGES: AFRICAN SCULPTURAL PAIRS. THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART, NEW YORK, NY. February 2004 - September 2004
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Double-bowled ceramic pot. The double form of this pot expresses the Mangbetu interest in symmetry, but it also derives from a double ritual pot that was used to hold a drink made from a hallucinogenic root. Among the Mangbetu, women usually made pottery, but anthropomorphic pots were made by men.
Publication History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. SCHILDKROUT, ENID AND CURTIS KEIM. EXHIBITION CATALOG. 1990

Exhibition History
• AFRICAN REFLECTIONS: ART FROM NORTHEASTERN ZAIRE. AMNH, NEW YORK, NY. June 1990 - February 1994
Exhibition Label: Ceramic pot. By 1900 Niangara was the center for the colonial administration, attracting artists from many different places who viewed one another's work and exchanged ideas. Most of the pottery Lang described as 'art pottery' was collected in Niangara, and in many instances the ethnic identity of the potter is unknown.

BASKET
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4714
Culture: MANGBETU?
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: PLANT FIBER
Dimensions: L:40.5 W:23 H:4.5 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: BASKET
Category: CONTAINERS
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Field Notes: ODUKU. Large basket showing different patterns, used for putting in food such as cooked or otherwise prepared bananas and vegetables also meat and fish. They take bananas leaves and hold it first over the fire. The leaves lose their rigidity and can be handled somewhat like paper. The midrib of the banana leaves is sliced away previously. With such prepared leaves the baskets are carefully laid out or the food is wrapped into. The food of the MANGBETU hereabout is also chiefly vegetable. The heavier sort like bananas are laid on the bottom, than the meat, if present, is folded in separate pieces of banana leaves. Oil, small fish cooked in oil mushrooms are brought in small dishes. All the work with regard to preparation of food is made by women. The baskets are made by men and women alike. The chief use of these baskets in OKONDO'S villages consists in covering the row of empty or filled large pots which decorate the interior of nearly every more conspicuous hut. Opposite the entrance alongside the wall they generally construct a sort of high bench that often runs along the wall from 1/3 to two thirds of its entire circumference. On former days these pots were all filled in the royal house either with oil or other articles and indicated the wealth of its owner. At the present time these pots are empty or a few contain things like string, dried leaves, etc. In some in OKONDO'S hut they put in glass bottles (of white men) filled with their ARAK, which they secretly distill. I h...ave not seen baskets of this sort elsewhere. As all the chiefs are polygamous, OKONDO for instance, must have at least a hundred wives and counting the servants, slaves and young girls, there are certainly more than two hundred women attached to his court. Each one of the more independent women is obliged to send to the royal kitchen baskets filled with food. Here the food of these baskets is put in large wooden dishes after being assorted, which is very simple considering the relative uniformity of the food delivered. It consists principally of prepared bananas, cooked manioc leaves and sometimes meat. This food is delivered to the ever present guests of the royal court. The food in general varies considerably, considering that nearly everything is considered comestible. Caterpillars, grasshoppers, termites, toads, frogs, snakes (they cut the head off), mice in fact everything is good eating. In OKONDO'S village they eat house rats that are despised so far as I could ascertain in all the region we visited further south, such tribes as the MEDJE, MALELE, MABUTU, MAYOKO, never eat house rats. OKONDO himself is very fond of rats which are delivered him by his natives spiked on sticks and smoked. The king at the present eats without any ceremony, before the crowd or his women, in native fashion with the fingers. I saw him eat banas [sic, bananas], sombe, mice, etc. Whenever he is hungry one of his women goes in the kitchen and brings something back wrapped in banana leaves. He lays it on the little bench and its it (at all times of the day). The principal meals, however, are in the early morning, at noon and near or after nightfall. NOTE: In 1913 he was no more eaten in the public places but either was eating in his hut or behind in one hut in which his sorcerers work the MAPINGA.Show More >>

HORN, FIGURE FEMALE
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4716
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: IVORY
Dimensions: L:55 W:7.4 (in CM)
Subject: FEMALE FIGURE
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: MUSICAL INSTRUMENT HORN
Category: SOUND DEVICES
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Curatorial Notes: The Mangbetu are groups of linguistically and culturally related peoples in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Like many neighboring West African peoples, their rich musical heritage has an important role in their communities.

Ivory horns were vital instruments for Mangbetu royalty; ivory has long been held as a highly prized material. The use of this precious ivory and the special labor involved in its production firmly linked ivory horns with the power of the king. Ivory horn production was delegated to exceptional smiths who used metals tools to carve the instrument from an animal tusk; these smiths also carved decorative images and motifs on the exterior of the horn, as seen on object 90.1/ 1794. Herbert Lang, head of the Museums 1915 Congo expedition during which these horns were collected, noted that many of these horns were adorned with an anthropomorphic carving on the mouthpiece, a decorative motif also found on Mangbetu harps. The length of the horns could be extended by attaching a wooden tube to the larger end of the instrument, a device that also deepened the sound of the horn. (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 202)

Ivory horn orchestras were primarily employed during court dances, such as the mabolo dance, in which the king danced alone in front of his subjects order to display his skill. The mabolo dance was designed to affirm the kings prestige because skillful dancing is equated with intelligence (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 205). Large ivory horns were also used to announce certain royal events, such as the mabolo dance, as well as the arrival and departure of a king, and victories in war. Smaller ivory horns, such as object 90.1/3660, were also carried by women during royal dances. Ivory horns were used to honor chiefs during the colonial period. (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 203).

Felix, Marc Leo. White Gold, Black Hands: Ivory Sculpture in Congo. Qiquhar, Heilungkiang, China: Gemini Sun, 2010.

Schildkrout, Enid, and Curtis A. Keim. African Reflections: Art from Northeastern Zaire. Seattle: U of Washington, 1990.

Research: Ava Muhr 2014
Field Notes: EMBONGO. Three ivory horns made by the king's artist. On small tusks they cut off the top, No. 1200 is one of the tips of the tusks. They take an ADZE and cut it roughly out as, for instance, the figure No. 1238. They cut it carefully with a knife like No.s 1155 & 1156 and smoothen it down with leaves that have a sandpaper-like surface. Formerly they had large ivory horns carved in about the same style but ivory has become somewhat precious and the chiefs are not inclined to make new horns as these horns are much appreciated. As soon as I can purchase a large tusk, his artist will prepare one for the museum's collection. They have been formerly used to communicate news from one agglomeration of MANGBETU to another, also during ceremonies and dances, and especially when visiting neighboring chiefs.

HARP
AFRICAN ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTION
 
Catalog No: 90.1/ 4722
Culture: MANGBETU
Locale: NIANGARA
Country: CONGO (BELGIAN CONGO)
Material: HIDE, WOOD, BARKCLOTH, PLANT FIBER, STAIN
Dimensions: L:69 W:17 H:10 (in CM)
Acquisition Year: 1915 [EXPEDITION]
Donor: LANG, HERBERT
Keywords: HARP
Category: SOUND DEVICES
Share Object
Add Object to Portfolio
Curatorial Notes: The Mangbetu are groups of linguistically and culturally related peoples in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Like many neighboring West African peoples, their rich musical heritage has an important role in their communities.

The Azande in the north, or the Mangebele and the Matchaga Bantu-speaking peoples in the south likely introduced harps to the Mangbetu during the mid nineteenth century (Schildkrout and Keim 1990: 198). Harp production among the Mangbetu proliferated during the colonial period, in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Individual musicians used them mainly as an accompaniment to particular songs, and they held relatively little musical importance in comparison to the ivory horns, slit drums, and iron bells employed in court music. They were actively collected by European traders and agents, who valued them more for their aesthetic qualities than as musical instruments. By the 1930s, harps had virtually disappeared from Mangbetu music. (Ross Miller 1992 : 51)

Standard material utilized in harp construction were wood, plant fiber, and animal hide. Animal pelts, such as leopard or okapi, as well as pangolin scales, and reptile skins were used decoratively on the hourglass or oval resonator. The addition of these decorative materials emphasizes the production of Mangbetu harps as art pieces rather than functioning musical instruments. There are stylistic similarities between Mangbetu and Azande harps, such as the traditional five strings, and anthropomorphic carvings along the stem of the instrument. (Perani and Smith 1998: 225). Mangbetu harps typically portray an elongated head that reflects a cultural expression of beauty that is achieved through cranial binding in infancy. The style in figurative expression can also be seen on some Azande harps. Mangbetu and Azande harps are differentiated by the location of the pegs; the Mangbetu are located on the right side, while the Azande are on the left. Further, Mangbetu harps do not have legs attached to the resonator, an anthropomorphic form employed only by the Azande. (Perani and Smith 1998: 225)

Perani, Judith, and Fred T. Smith. The Visual Arts of Africa: Gender, Power, and Life Cycle Rituals. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 1998.

Ross Miller, Thomas. The Evidence of Instruments. Anthropology & Humanism, Volume 17, Issue 2, (June 1992): pp. 49-60.

Schildkrout, Enid, and Curtis A. Keim. African Reflections: Art from Northeastern Zaire. Seattle: U of Washington, 1990.

Research: Ava Muhr 2014
Field Notes: EDOMO. A sort of harp-like instrument much used by the MANGBETU, only played by men. See photograph. Often accompanied by a somewhat monotonous song. Much appreciated. No. 1352 has string of rattan. No. 1353 and 1354 has been covered with skin of leopard, presented by OKONDO = (Leopard). The strings of these harps are usually of the fibres of the oil palm.
